item.title: Louvre Heist Was Caught on Film, Officials Say, Rebutting Earlier Account
item.description: Investigators said that a security camera recorded thieves preparing to burgle the Louvre, but that guards didn’t watch the feed in time. The museum’s director had previously said the camera was facing the wrong way.

item.title: Yemeni Separatists Set Sights on Houthi-Controlled Capital
item.description: The Southern Transitional Council has seized control of parts of Yemen over the past week, with ambitions to create a “south Arabian state.”

item.title: Danish Intelligence Report Raises Concerns About Shifts in US Policy Under Trump
item.description: A new document cites Washington’s shifting strategic priorities and growing pressure on allies under President Trump as sources of uncertainty for Denmark.

item.title: U.S. Plans to Scrutinize 5 Years of Social Media History for Foreign Tourists
item.description: Even visitors from countries like Britain and France, whose citizens don’t need visas, would be required to share five years’ worth of social media.

item.title: Venezuela’s Nobel Peace Prize Winner Says She Will Appear in Oslo After Missing Ceremony
item.description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, said she was on her way to Norway after living in hiding in her country, where officials have threatened her with arrest.

item.title: Khmer Rouge-Era Land Mines Have a Big Role in Thailand-Cambodia Conflict
item.description: Thailand says ordnance replanted by Cambodia has injured or maimed more than a dozen of its soldiers. Cambodia rejects the accusation.

item.title: ISIS Detention Camps Pose a Dangerous Problem for Syria’s Leaders
item.description: The government faces a dilemma over what to do with civil-war-era prisons and detention camps that hold thousands of ISIS fighters and tens of thousands of their family members.

item.title: The Territorial Sticking Point Between Russia and Ukraine
item.description: The Kremlin says any peace deal must cede to Russia the entire eastern Donbas region, including territory Ukraine still controls — a nonstarter for Kyiv.

item.title: The Challenges to Europe’s Security Go Beyond Trump’s Lack of Support
item.description: Europeans find themselves stranded between hostile powers, Russia and the United States, with key decisions looming over the future of Ukraine.

item.title: Australia’s Social Media Ban for Children Takes Effect
item.description: The measure, which affects anyone under 16, is one of the most sweeping efforts in the world to safeguard young people from the potential harms of the platforms.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize for Venezuela’s María Corina Machado Draws Criticism
item.description: María Corina Machado is being honored for her push for democracy even as she backs President Trump’s military buildup and aggressive campaign against Venezuela.

item.title: Chip Company Plotted to Send Technology to China, Ex-C.E.O. Says
item.description: The former chief executive of Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker, said Dutch officials had known for years that the company’s Chinese owner sought to move its technology to China.

item.title: Trump and Europe’s Far Right
item.description: The American national security strategy echoes the language of far-right parties. But hardliners across the Atlantic seem unimpressed.

item.title: Seattle’s Plans for a Pride Match at World Cup Infuriates Iran and Egypt
item.description: The two countries, which criminalize homosexuality and impose severe punishments for it, were picked to play on a day celebrating L.G.B.T.Q. communities.

item.title: Inside the Pentagon’s Scramble to Deal With Boat Strike Survivors
item.description: Officials initially weighed sending survivors of U.S. attacks on boats suspected of drug smuggling to a notorious prison in El Salvador, to keep them away from American courts.

item.title: Ukraine Could Be ‘Ready for Elections,’ Zelensky Says
item.description: The Ukrainian president told reporters that a vote could be held in 60 to 90 days if the country received security protections from the United States.

item.title: Kirsten Hillman, Canada’s Ambassador to U.S., to Leave Post
item.description: Kirsten Hillman, who came to Washington during the first Trump administration, had already extended her tenure once.

item.title: For Real, a Natural History of Misinformation
item.description: It’s not just humans who suffer from leading one another astray. So do fish, flies and even bacteria.

item.title: Canada Plans to Fast-Track Immigration for US H1-B Visa Holders in New Talent Drive
item.description: The government says it will fast-track immigration for U.S. H-1B visa holders and spend more than $1 billion to attract researchers from the United States and the rest of the world.

item.title: Love Letters From a Chinese Jail
item.description: The torn pieces of paper by Gao Zhen, a renowned artist jailed in China, show family portraits, memories of New York and expressions of faith. To his wife, they are love letters.

item.title: Israeli Ban on Media Entering Gaza Remains, as Legal Challenge Is Delayed
item.description: Israel’s top court gave the government further reprieve on a long-stalled petition seeking free access to Gaza. Critics say barring journalists denies the world a full picture of conditions there.

item.title: Brigitte Macron’s Slur Against Feminist Protesters Prompts an Outcry in France
item.description: Brigitte Macron used a slur to criticize protesters who had interrupted a show by a French comedian accused of rape in 2021, in a case that was dismissed.

item.title: Iain Douglas-Hamilton, Who Studied, and Protected, Elephants, Dies at 83
item.description: Born into an aristocratic British family, he turned his empathy and knowledge of the world’s largest land mammals to the cause of saving them from poachers.

item.title: Staying Informed and Not Overwhelmed in 2026
item.description: We are asking readers to share their tips for coping with the news.

item.title: A History of U.S. Military Action in Latin America
item.description: The United States’ history in the region includes several about-faces, contradictions and missteps.

item.title: Hundreds of Thousands of Thais and Cambodians Flee
item.description: People escaped from a deadly border conflict, the authorities said, with some sheltering at a racetrack in Thailand and others near temples in Cambodia.

item.title: Canada’s Northwest Territories Diamond Mines Are Closing
item.description: After decades of growth driven by diamond mining, Canada’s Northwest Territories are facing the closure of three major mines and wondering: What’s next?

item.title: Lithuania Declares National Emergency Over Suspicious Balloons From Belarus
item.description: Hundreds of weather balloons sent to Lithuania this year have disrupted flights and stirred alarm in a sabotage campaign against a NATO state.

item.title: The Conflict Over Nigeria’s Returned Treasures
item.description: Western museums are returning the Benin Bronzes — priceless items looted during colonialism — to Nigeria, but political infighting has jeopardized the ability to display and maintain the masterpieces. Our reporter, Alex Marshall, traveled to Nigeria to see some of the Bronzes.

item.title: Another Front in the War in Ukraine: Who Gets to Claim a Famed Artist?
item.description: Looking to shake off Moscow’s cultural influences, Kyiv has been seeking to highlight the Ukrainian roots of Kazimir Malevich, a renowned avant-garde painter.

item.title: All 187,460 Miles of Road That Led to Rome, Mapped
item.description: A digital atlas of ancient Rome’s highways and byways reveals a road network that was more extensive than thought.

item.title: 7.6-Magnitude Earthquake Near Japan Triggers Tsunami Warning
item.description: The 7.6-magnitude quake struck in waters off Aomori Prefecture on Japan’s main island, Honshu. It triggered a tsunami warning, which was later lifted.

item.title: Honduras Issues Arrest Warrant for Hernández, Ex-President Pardoned by Trump
item.description: The attorney general said he had asked Interpol to detain Juan Orlando Hernández, who was freed from a U.S. prison last week.

item.title: The Second ‘China Shock’
item.description: Chinese exports are flooding the developing world, and the social consequences are bound to be profound.

item.title: With Cheap Tickets and Lax Etiquette, a Theater Builds an Older Fan Base
item.description: The Hollywood Classic cinema in Seoul is popular in a country where 70-year-olds now outnumber people in their 20s.

item.description: After deadly cross-border military clashes, the Pakistani and Afghan governments have locked their populations in a trade war threatening the livelihoods of millions.

item.title: Marooned Off the English Coast: Lots of Bananas
item.description: Containers of bananas, avocados and plantains fell off a cargo ship off the Isle of Wight. A soggy fruit harvest ensued.

item.title: One Hundred Schoolchildren Released After Kidnapping in Nigeria
item.description: The abduction of over 260 children from a Catholic school last month was the latest in a recent spate of kidnappings in the country.

item.description: Russell Bonner Bentley III, 64, who was living in the occupied Donbas region of Ukraine, was beaten and tortured to death after he was suspected of being an American saboteur, investigators said.

item.title: Trump Criticizes Zelensky as Ukraine Peace Talks Drag On With European Leaders
item.description: Despite pressure from the Trump administration, Mr. Zelensky, after meeting with European leaders who vowed continued support in the war, said Ukraine’s position on territory had not changed.

item.description: Each side accused the other of firing first. The hostilities came weeks after President Trump had cast himself as a peacemaker in the decades-old border dispute.

item.description: Municipal officials say the action was about unpaid taxes. The U.N. relief agency for Palestinians says it is exempt from taxes and should be immune from such a raid, calling it illegal.

item.title: Syrians Celebrate Anniversary of Bashar al-Assad’s Fall
item.description: A year ago, rebels overthrew President Bashar al-Assad, ending decades of dictatorship and civil war. But challenges remain for the new leadership.

item.title: Attacks on Kindergarten and Hospital Kill 114 in Sudan, W.H.O. Says
item.description: The drone strikes were blamed on the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, extending a pattern of atrocities in Sudan’s 2½-year civil war.

item.title: Collector Surrenders ‘Nude Emperor’ Statue Identified as Looted
item.description: The statue and a marble head of a Greek orator seized from the Met Museum were among dozens of items found to have been looted that were handed over to Turkey at a ceremony in Manhattan.

item.title: Why Russian Spies Are Using Mexico to Target the U.S.

item.description: Moscow has ramped up covert operations in Mexico, with spies meeting handlers in its bustling capital and seaside resorts, U.S. officials say.

item.description: The latest violence comes months after President Trump helped mediate a cease-fire between the two nations.

item.description: A cease-fire after two years of war with Israel has allowed Hamas to tighten its grip on power again. “It’s still standing,” one Israeli official said.

item.title: Firefighter Is Killed as Multiple Wildfires Burn in Australia
item.description: The firefighter died after being struck by a tree. Dozens of homes in two states have been lost as hot, windy conditions point to a challenging fire season.

item.title: United Nations Cuts Its 2026 Emergency Aid Budget in Half
item.description: Huge reductions in foreign aid by the United States and Europe have led the U.N.’s emergency relief coordinator to slash its fund-raising targets for next year.
